results.title: Stone and gum working
results.creator_credit: Ian Dunlop, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode number 13 of Series “People of the Australian western desert”.
Shows a man making tools, using gum obtained from a species of spinifex grass and quartz collected from a nearby quarry.

results.title: Stone age technology
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Quantum”.
In this short segment from Quantum, we are shown the unique stone-age technology of quartz cutting, developed by the Australian Aborigines some 20,000 years ago. The technique for cutting quartz is quite different and more sophisticated than that used for flint and had to be invented here, although it was a skill later discarded by the Aborigines.

results.title: Stone
results.brief_description: Several members of a bikie gang are mysteriously murdered. An undercover cop becomes the man in the middle trying to both protect the bikies and prevent them from taking venegeance. The film is perhaps more convincing as an exploration of a lifestyle than as a thriller with a series of conventionally conceived and effectively staged stunts and chases backed by a heavy rock score. With a box-office return of around ten times the $195,000 budget, ‘Stone’ ranks with films like ‘Alvin Purple’ as the most successful pre-Croc Australian feature. Cast includes Ken Shorter, Sandy Harbutt, Helen Morse, Vincent Gil, Hugh Keays-Byrne, Rebecca Gilling, Roger Ward, Bill Hunter and Gary McDonald.

results.title: Stomp out loud
results.brief_description: Visually rhythmic and stylish production depicting the renowned stage show, STOMP, as they take their percussion, movement and visual comedy to various settings in New York. It is a virtually wordless video clip style work which follows the STOMP troupe as they tour New York, taking their beats using everyday objects to audiences in live performances and simple to elaborate outdoor and indoor locations. The images and sounds speak for themselves as the performers unleash their energy and versatility on pots and pans, cutlery and crockery, drains, playing cards, rubbish bins, buckets and brooms to name a few and combine them with their own tap style dance and physical theatre to express the extraordinary sounds and rhythmic potential of the world around and within us.

results.title: Stolen moments
results.creator_credit: Margaret Wescott, Silva Basmajian and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: Narrated by Kate Nelligan, the film takes us on an odyssey across North America and Europe to capture the ‘stolen moments’ of lesbian history. Lesbian culture in pre-war Paris, Berlin and Amsterdam; the experience of women in Nazi concentration camps; and the butch/femme scene in New York in the 1950s, are just a few aspects of lesbian history and identity explored in this provocative film. Writers Joan Nestle, Leslie Feinberg and Audrey Lorde share their insights of love, life, sexual politics and feminism. The film also explores such contemporary cultural scenes as women’s motorcycle clubs, dance bars, lesbian stand-up comedy, the Michigan Women’s Music Festival and lesbian athletes and their participation at the Vancouver Gay Games. A press kit complements the video and is issued as a separate loan item.

results.title: Stolen kisses = Baisers voles
results.creator_credit: Francois Truffaut, Marcel Berbert, Les Productions Artistes Associes and Les Films du Carrosse
results.brief_description: The romantic and carefree nature of a young Frenchman in 1960s Paris is explored in this the third film by Truffaut to feature the character Antoine Doinel. Antoine is dishonourably discharged from the army and sets about to find himself a new job and to be re-acquainted with his girlfriend Michelle. Along the way he ends up as a private detective set with the task of disguising himself as a stock boy in a shoe store to find out why the staff don’t like the boss. He himself ends up being rather taken with the boss’s wife! Cast includes Jean-Pierre Leaud, Delphine Seyrig, Claude Jade, and Michel Lonsdale. Disc also includes another short Truffaut film “Antoine and Colette”, shot in black and white. Antoine Doinel falls for a music student, but spends an evening with her parents while she’s out on a date. Available on 16mm title number X000897.

results.title: Stocking Up
results.brief_description: Vic and Betty Sussman demonstrate home food preservation, including freezing and canning. They emphasise inexpensive, low energy techniques such as root cellaring and drying, and explain the nutritional and financial advantages of each method.
results.description: Vic and Betty Sussman demonstrate home food preservation, including freezing and canning. They emphasise inexpensive, low energy techniques such as root cellaring and drying, and explain the nutritional and financial advantages of each method.

results.title: Stock exchange & takeovers
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Economics”.
(HSC economic series) A comprehensive introduction to the stock exchange and takeovers. Covers the reason for having a stock exchange and how it works; buying and selling; how the public is informed; defines takeovers and their motivation; explains how are they made and if they are good or bad for the economy. No other credits available.

results.title: Stirring the pool
results.creator_credit: Gil Brealey, Peter Weir, Commonwealth Public Service Board and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Personnel or People”.
A new typist is asked to do a job for the manager instead of the senior typist, who is not present. Afterwards the senior typist voices her resentment, causing the new girl to feel unhappy. Another typist informs the new typist that the attitude of the senior typist is not new and has caused many resignations. What is the answer to internal warfare in the typing pool? Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Stirring
results.creator_credit: Jane Oehr, Timothy Read and Film Australia
results.brief_description: The film has been produced to demonstrate how a teacher approaches the controversial issue of the use of corporal punishment in schools. It includes class discussions with the boys in a high school in New South Wales, role playing and discussions with other teachers and with people outside the school. The boys also raise issues such as the communication barriers existing between teachers and students, the repressive aspects of school life, and the possibility of change.
